Comments_List: I learned a lot about the field of philosophy as well as about how philosophers approach difficult questions.
Learned a lot about philosophy, play and games, which sound like niche topics but are actually super relevant. Great introduction to philosophy in a super engaging, fun and meaningful manner.
Reading and responding to philosophical texts and learning how to write a philosophy paper.

In taking this class, I learned an incredible amount about the world of philosophy of games. I learned topics like strategy in games, how to define games, the metric of intrinsic value in games, applications of what could be considered a game. Overall, I learned a lot in instigating conversations with friends about contentious topics like "is a race a game?" and the importance of games in our society.
I became a more critical thinker and learned a lot about philosophy, particularly in its application to games.
A different mode of thinking, what constitutes a game.
I gained a deeper understanding of the process of philosophy in general, as well as its application to games in particular. I also improved my academic writing.
I gained an in-depth review of games as well as a chance to interact with an amazing professor.
I learned how to make arguments in the field of philosophy and I learned how to participate in class discussions.
I developed a deeper understanding of how games factor into our daily lives and what exactly they are. Previously, I was unaware of how immersed in games and gameplay we are.
I learned about how to think and rationalize philosophically and how to discuss my ideas within a group.

I learned how to think differently, not logically or linearly but more abstractly. I consider myself to be a STEM student and never thought I'd take a philosophy class but somehow I ended up here and I loved it.  Philosophy is an extremely interesting subject and I'd never thought to look at the concept of games from this perspective.
I learned how to read and write the language of philosophy.
Very fun class, but a decent amount of reading.

Course was fantastic. Don't think it can really be improved. Anyone interested in philosophy should take this as their first choice, but don't take it unless you are generally interested in philosophy because you'll take away spots from people who really do care.
Mark Maxwell is a great professor and makes the discussions interesting and engaging.

The strengths of this course were the breadth and depth of the topics discussed in the field. I think that dedicating an entire class session to one or two sets of readings was enough to get a valuable insight into the topic at hand without being overbearing or dry. I really liked the seminar-style discussion format and how Professor Maxwell asked stimulating questions to engage dialogue while inputting relevant, interesting feedback. 

The only thing I could see that could improve the course would be maybe incorporating more of a heads up on irrelevant jargon or sections to skip on our readings, because sometimes it got confusing and I didn't realize until we began discussing it in class that no one really understood what it said. The professor did offer some of this insight beforehand in the previous class, but I would appreciate even more. I also highly, highly, highly would like to see the readings being posted entirely in advance so that it would easier for students to get ahead on the readings and get them done for the week, rather than have to Google them or email the professor and find them themselves.

Strengths - interesting material, direction from Professor Maxwell, discussion in seminar
Weakness - some of the readings were quite challenging

Strengths: readings are very interesting, and professor is very accessible
Weaknesses: Sometimes readings changed so it was difficult to know exactly what readings needed to be done.
The main strength of the course lies in the in-class discussions revolving around the various aspects of games. On a few occasions we played games in class, which was fun and stimulating.
There are a lot of super interesting readings in the class and it's a very interesting theme, but we would sometimes get sidetracked with somewhat irrelevant discussion.

It teaches students how to effectively read and digest philosophical essays as well as think critically of everyday topics. However, the course did not help students with philosophical writing. Since it was an introductory course, I feel as if there should have been more structure built into the course to help students improve their philosophical writing skills. Additionally, I feel the course lacked periodic instructor feedback.

Strengths: interesting topics, good discussion led, fair amount of work and assignments
Weaknesses: tended to move off topic quite a bit into random discussions, sometimes these were good but sometimes not

This class covered very interesting material. The readings and thus the workload was manageable. Discussions were always entertaining and interesting. A weakness is that sometimes we spent too much time on a topic and other times we would spend too little time on a topic but of course that's subjective to what I found engaging.
I would because it taught me a lot about philosophy in a low-stakes environment
Absolutely! Mark is a fantastic professor and the seminars and readings were super engaging. Take it if you can!
Yes, I would recommend this course. It is an interesting way to look at games and how they relate to life in general.

I 100% would recommend this course to another student simply because the discussion of games in society is a niche topic that is difficult to explore anywhere outside of college. This course has changed the way I view the world and even Life in examining what I think is a game and what the value of games is. It's such an interesting course that's taught so well that I can't recommend the class enough.

Absolutely

Yes!! Mark is an awesome professor and this is an amazing freshman seminar. Personally, I'm very glad I took this class because it really helped me get used to college level readings without a lot of pressure and I got to engage in a topic that I'd never thought to learn about. This class also inspired me to take more philosophy classes because I surprisingly discovered that I really enjoy philosophy. And I also now know a lot about games and how to define a game.
Absolutely, it is a low stress course but extremely rewarding.
